title: Why you shouldn't buy the Disney Infinity 3.0 Star Wars Starter Pack...yet - Andy Robertson
text:
With the Star Wars figures and video-game adventures of Disney Infinity 3.0 available at retail parents can now decide whether the game offers good value and how best to buy it.
While this year’s Disney Infinity 3.0 Star Wars Starter Pack (£45) is priced lower than last year , and offers plenty of play value, there are a few things to consider before investing.
If you are after the classic Episode IV-VI content at launch via the Rise Against the Empire play-set then you may need to go for the more expensive Special Edition starter pack (£89).
Video loading
A better solution however is to wait for a month whereupon you can purchase the Rise of the Empire play-set adventure on its own.
Better still, purchasing the stand alone disc version of the game (£25) re-uses last year's USB.
Base peripheral and can be paired with any play-set so families can buy just the content they want to play.
This is a good route for families who want children to encounter the Star Wars films in the “correct” order they were originally released and start with just Episodes IV-VI.
The Disc Only route to purchase is also a good way to access content for non-Star Wars families - apparently there are some. The Inside Out play-set is available now and a Marvel Battlegrounds adventure is expected later on.
Video loading
Another consideration is the toy-box game creator mode. Buying the disc on its own provides access to all the 3.0 toy-box features.
Here players can spend many hours creating, sharing and downloading home-made game adventures.
The final piece of content to consider is the Toy Box Speed Way and Take Over packs.
These take the idea of last year’s toy-box mini-games to the next level.
The Toy Box Take Over is an action platform game that can be played with any of your Disney Infinity character collection. This is available now for £13.99 and can be used with the Disc Only or Starter Pack game.
Similarly, Toy Box Speed Way is a Mario Kart style game featuring all manner of Disney Characters, and again supports all your old Disney Infinity collection.
Those new to Disney Infinity should also consider purchasing the older games. The play-set adventures for these older versions can’t be played with the new game and are some real hidden gems.
For example, buying Disney Infinity 1.0 Starter Pack (around £22) will grant access to play-set adventures including Pirates of the Caribbean, The Incredibles, Cars, Monsters University, Toy Story and The Lone Ranger.
Many of these are available at a fraction of the cost second hand.
The Disney Infinity 2.0 Starter Pack (around £29) opens the door to various Marvel adventures for Guardians of the Galaxy, Spider-Man and The Avengers.
The PC game is another good value route. The latest 3.0 game won’t come to PC for a while but in the meantime Disney Infinity 2.0 on PC offers great value as both the characters and play sets can be purchased without the associated toys as a fraction of the cost.
The tablet version offers similar value although it is restricted to the toy-box mode.
Video loading
On the figurine side, there are a few considerations too.
Firstly if you are purchasing a character for use in a particular play-set that is not their original Star Wars era you need to collect the Cross-Over coins before they can be used.
Darth Vader, for example, can’t be used in the Twilight of the Republic play-set before you have collected his Cross-Over coins in the video-game.
It’s also worth noting that there are special Light FX Star Wars figures releasing later will have light-up elements. Although functioning similarly in the game these look much more impressive on the Infinity Base with their lightsabers glowing.
While collectors will no doubt purchase both versions, families planning to buy Luke Skywalker, Darth Vader, Anakin Skywalker, Yoda, Obi-Wan Kenobi or Kanan Jarrus may want to wait until these special light-up editions characters are released.
While there is a lot to consider here, get the combinations right and Disney Infinity 3.0 has a lot of value to offer families, although this may not necessarily be via the Star Wars Starer Pack.
